author: Vjaz
text: narkceh, because you're trying to open /etc/modules as a regular user. what you're doing is essentially running "echo fglrx" with sudo and redirecting it to /etc/modules. You should run "sudo -s" or "sudo su -" and then run "echo fglrx >> /etc/modules"

text: babigeneric: make your bind server a slave to ms server, tell ms server your linux server is allowed zone transfers.  Bring up bind and query and name.  Bind will bring copies of the dns over, change the domain in bind from slave to master.  You're done.

author: j_ayen_green
text: running lucid. this morning, the screen was black, and I couldn't get a response. It's running in vbox, so after about 45 minutes, I just shut it down. It turns out that it was doing a full backup, because I had forgotten to mount the network drive where the backups are kept, so it was treating the mount point as a local directory, found no interim backups, and so began a full. Is there some...

author: scampbell
text: j_ayen_green: trick for the future.  Remove all permissions on the mountpoints (when they aren't mounted).  chmod a-rwx /mountpoint.   When mounted it will have whatever permissions the media wants, when not it's untouchable so that sort thing stands right up instead of hosing all your disk space.

author: ubottu
text: To replicate your packages selection on another machine (or restore it if re-installing), you can type  aptitude  --display-format '%p' search '?installed!?automatic' > ~/my-packages , move the file "my-packages" to the other machine, and there type  sudo xargs aptitude --schedule-only install < my-packages ; sudo aptitude install  - See also !automate

text: i want to deal with latest openssl vuln. CVE-2014-0224.  As per suggestion i did apt-get update and upgrade on my system (ubuntu 10.01 LTS) and openssl version upgraded to 0.9.8k-7ubuntu8.18 from 0.9.8k-7ubuntu8.15. but my external tool says that it is still vulnerable. I am not sure what to do. as per other suggestion i should upgrade to .za but not sure how to do this ?

author: ubottu
text: OpenSSL before 0.9.8za, 1.0.0 before 1.0.0m, and 1.0.1 before 1.0.1h does not properly restrict processing of ChangeCipherSpec messages, which allows man-in-the-middle attackers to trigger use of a zero-length master key in certain OpenSSL-to-OpenSSL communications, and consequently hijack sessions or obtain sensitive information, via a crafted TLS handshake, aka the "CCS Injec... (http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-0224)

author: skrrp
text: chmod is the command to change file permissions. permissions are read, write, execute (rwx) for user, group, all (uga). if you chmod a-x (all minus execute) then only the owner of the file and groups (ug) will be able to run the file

author: skrrp
text: Guest7100: install BSD. joking aside there are many small and big things you can do to secure your system. start with sshd_config. move the ssh port to a high number in the user range, disable root login. use nmap to scan your system for open ports (services). disable any you don't need. kill inetd if it's running. kill any insecure ftp programs. you might consider a firewall (shorewall) or...

author: skrrp
text: ...selinux. you could opt for just not having ports open rather than firewalls. read up on port knocking if you are truly paranoid

author: darius93
text: I have a question about shred, it is said that it zeros the file (or partition if one decide to use that feature) but when it comes to zeroing a file, why does it run so fast? I havent tried using it with a partition but if I use dd to destroy a file, it takes slightly longer depending on if its a hdd, ssd, whats io operations going on on disk, etc

author: rypervenche
text: darius93: If you're using dd on a disk, it's using 512 bytes by default, which is extremely slow. If you were to use 32M for example for the byte size, it would go much more quickly.

author: darius93
text: Ah that explains it but I generally use 1M

author: rypervenche
text: darius93: I've also found shred to be a little slow, but I've never done a side-by-side. They are both binaries that do different things, so yeah.

author: geirha
text: newuser789: the file is split into sizable pieces, then checksums for each piece is stored in the .zsync file.  When you download with zsync, you provide it with similar files you've already downloaded. It checks those files if they have any matching pieces, and only downloads any missing ones.

author: Gnomethrower
text: Hey everyone. I was wondering if anyone knows a tool like fuser or lsof that works on FUSE filesystems when they crash

author: ikonia
text: fuse file system ?

author: ikonia
text: it's not actually a file system, it's just how it's presented to the user over the network

author: ikonia
text: eg: samba - is not actually a file system

author: Gnomethrower
text: specifically, if MooseFS or LizardFS or GlusterFS FUSE client crashes, with dir /storage/lfs as the mountpoint, I can't umount /storage/lfs until I kill anything using it. lsof and fuser however are useless in this scenario and do not work with crashed FUSE mountpoints

author: Gnomethrower
text: ikonia: in this case I'm talking about actual filesystems. I'm aware FUSE is for other stuff too

author: ikonia
text: Gnomethrower: what file system are you actually talking about then

author: _peter_
text: @search pease

author: Gnomethrower
text: ikonia: LizardFS in this case, but we've seen the same behaviour from Gluster and MooseFS

author: ikonia
text: Gnomethrower: isn't this the same situation as any remote userspace mount, as then the mount goes the userdata/status is lost

author: ikonia
text: so when you remount tools like lsof won't show anything

author: hotspot
text: anybody know how to change channel on the ubuntu hotspot or some other software to create a hotspot without AP mode?

author: ikonia
text: so you fix it on the server which the file system is not a userspace mount, it's a local file system

author: Gnomethrower
text: ikonia: I'm not worried about remounting losing the status

author: Gnomethrower
text: ikonia: I'm wanting to unmount it from a client, but it won't let me while for example nginx is running

author: Gnomethrower
text: and usually lsof/fuser would tell you what to kill to be able to successfully umount

author: Gnomethrower
text: but lsof and fuser do not work on a crashed FUSE mountpoint

author: Gnomethrower
text: okay, apparently this is a kernel limitation and there's really no easy solution

author: Gnomethrower
text: so consider my question solved I guess
